text: Hey guys, I’m working with a graphic designer that is new to web design, are there any great resources you guys would recommend?
Working as a web designer for a few years
Kidding, let me dig up some stuff
haha yea I do feel it’s one of those things where you learn the most by doing. I just want to help him get a good start
Is he/she designing mockups in sketch or photoshop?
we’re not sure what tool we’ll have him use. Maybe adobe XD. but otherwise probably photoshop

<http://www.pristinemedia.com/sites/1080gs/about/> - For grid website design. I would also recommend signing up for an envato elements account. <https://elements.envato.com/> - There are lots of good designs that you can get inspiration from and also see how elements were made in sketch/photoshop.

So when we work with designers who are coming from a print background I usually tell them:
1.) Keep everything inside of a 1440 wide box
2.) No adjusting the width of text boxes to eliminate orphans
3.) Consistent margins and padding around sections and elements.
4.) Full-width images will be scaling with the screen size
5.) All elements have to be constrained by rules, there can’t be any (it just looks nice over there in this case) Erase the idea of one-off element styling.
6.) No random flair elements that sometimes appear behind a random section
7.) Start with a style guide that outlines the type styles and colors and don’t stray from it
8.) Don’t try to measure from the baseline of a font.
9.) Photo filters don’t exist in all browsers
10.) Think about how everything will stack on mobile.
` All elements have to be constrained by rules, there can't be any (it just looks nice over there in this case) Erase the idea of one-off element styling.`
reading through your messages. Thank you guys seriously, good stuff.
I feel like this needs to be on a poster
I hate email templates.

when I get projects like that I’m like - “what’s your budget and what’s your time frame?”

They usually go “200 bucks for this email”
“for 200 I can do this” _screenshots their mockup crossing out almost everything._

serious props again on this straight to the point list. We thought it was good enough that we litterally sat down with the designer and went through each thing.

This is a great list. Only thing I would add is to try and avoid raster layers as much as possible (not 100% that that's the right way to phrase that, but it's the best I can think of right now). For example, create a rectangle or other shape with a fill property rather than creating a new pixel layer, selecting an area, then filing in a color or gradient. Makes it way easier to get the true color values, and move things if we need to. Another example, instead of cropping an image in photoshop, create a mask to hide the excess rather than deleting it all together.

Oh, and paragraph text should be wrapped paragraph text, not a bunch of soft breaks where they look good :sweat_smile: I love it when I copy text out of a PS document and there are &nbsp;s everywhere </s>
Oh jeez yeah that’s a popular mistake
I would say that for logos and icons you need to make sure that the linked files are twice the size that they’ll appear. Especially if you’re using Sketch since they’ll be super easy to export.
Glad to help with the list!
<@U22PKFRU5> I see a HS article or best practices page coming out of this
I’m starting a blog that is the opposite of this.
Completely terrible advice
haha
I bought worstpractices.cool
I figured the .cool domain would be the first worst practice

back when i was in college a group of friends and I had an idea to start an agency together, our marketing plan was to brand our company based on a band of super heros, and we even had a rival league of villains called “The Comic Sands”(yes comic sans joke intended)

and our plan was litterally to create facebook pages and a site for the comic sands and the whole idea was that “company” would be polar opposite of what we were. promoting bad practices, and crappy work
in a humerous way
Playing both sides!
your idea just reminded me of that lol
Genius

yea, gotta admit I wish we had atleast finished our website, we got fairly far in the marketing materials then basically 1 person got lazy or felt overwhelmed and it fell apart.

All of us in the company had a custom superhero character designed that both reflected our strengths and personality. Our plan was to use our super hero character names as our job titles.
I would be Professor X, because I am constantly in a chair and I can read marketing manager’s minds.
tried to find the drawing of my character, could only find one of someone elses, <https://spin.d.pr/BRYt2g>

everyone’s characters had already been sketched out we were at the stage of getting em digitally inked, and detailed and a few of them got pretty far but then the person who was digitally inking em flaked and disappeared
forget what the name of this character was.
I would also send them to go read up on atomic design
<http://atomicdesign.bradfrost.com/table-of-contents/>
Earlier in my design life, that changed how I thought about web elements and has definitely impacted me as I've floated between designer/developer land
